summary: This is the trust agreement for 'The 1953 Trust', an amendment and restatement of the Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust, executed by Jeffrey E. Epstein on August 8, 2019. It details the administration of the trust during his life and after his death, including extensive bequests to numerous individuals, the transfer of major properties, and the appointment of trustees and successor trustees. The document is significant as it outlines Epstein's posthumous financial plans and reveals a network of beneficiaries and associates.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: The creator and grantor of the trust, who reserves extensive powers to amend, revoke, and withdraw from the trust during his lifetime. He designates numerous beneficiaries and specific bequests.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Named as a trustee of The 1953 Trust and the operating expense trusts. He is also a major beneficiary set to receive $50 million and has loans forgiven.

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.context: Named as a trustee of The 1953 Trust and the operating expense trusts. He is a beneficiary set to receive $25 million and has loans forgiven.

persons.name: Karyna Shuliak
persons.context: The primary beneficiary designated to receive $50 million, a $50 million annuity, and multiple major properties (Zorro Ranch, Little St. James, Great St. James, Paris apartments, Palm Beach, and New York properties), along with jewelry and diamonds.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $10 million from the trust.

persons.name: Lawrence Paul Visoski, Jr.
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $10 million and has his outstanding financial obligations to Epstein's entities forgiven upon Epstein's death.

persons.name: Bella Klein
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $3 million and has her outstanding financial obligations to Epstein's entities forgiven.

persons.name: Luciano A. Fontanilla, Jr.
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $3 million, is forgiven any loans, and is to receive Epstein's interest in the property at 18 Teneyck Avenue, Valley Stream, New York.

persons.name: Merwin Dela Cruz
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $3 million and has his outstanding financial obligations to Epstein's entities forgiven.

persons.name: Valdson Viera Contrin
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $5 million.

persons.name: Ann Rodriquez
persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $5 million and has her outstanding financial obligations to Epstein's entities forgiven.

persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $10 million, to be held in trust for the benefit of his children.

persons.context: Named as a beneficiary to receive $3 million if married to Darren K. Indyke at Epstein's death, specifically to repay a real estate contract. Also referenced as Darren Indyke's spouse in loan forgiveness clauses.

connections.description: Epstein appoints Indyke as a trustee of his trust and designates him as a major beneficiary ($50M). The document also references entities owned by Indyke and forgives his financial obligations.
Epstein appoints Kahn as a trustee of his trust and designates him as a major beneficiary ($25M). The document forgives his financial obligations.
Epstein designates Shuliak as the primary beneficiary, set to receive $50M, a $50M annuity, multiple high-value properties, jewelry, and diamonds.
Epstein designates Maxwell as a beneficiary to receive $10 million from the trust.
Saipher is referenced as Indyke's spouse in clauses regarding loan forgiveness and a specific $3M bequest contingent on their marriage.
Lisa Kahn is referenced as Richard Kahn's spouse in clauses regarding the forgiveness of his financial obligations.
Eileen Visoski is referenced as Lawrence Visoski's spouse in clauses regarding the forgiveness of his financial obligations.
Visoski is a beneficiary ($10M) and has his financial obligations to Epstein's entities forgiven, indicating a close financial and employment relationship.
Klein is a beneficiary ($3M) and has her financial obligations to Epstein's entities forgiven.
Fontanilla is a beneficiary ($3M), has loans forgiven, and is to receive a specific property (18 Teneyck Avenue).

events.title: Execution of The 1953 Trust Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey E. Epstein signs the trust agreement amending and restating his earlier 2019 trust, creating 'The 1953 Trust' and outlining his posthumous estate plan.

events.title: Prior Trust Amendment
events.description: Epstein exercised his right to amend the original Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust, as referenced in the preamble of this document.

events.title: Establishment of Original Trust
events.description: The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust was originally established with Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn as Trustees.

locations: Little St. James Island, St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands

Great St. James, U.S. Virgin Islands
358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida
9 East 71st Street, New York, New York
18 Teneyck Avenue, Valley Stream, New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein created 'The 1953 Trust' on August 8, 2019, amending a trust established earlier that year, and reserved extensive control over the assets during his lifetime.
The trust designates Karyna Shuliak as the primary beneficiary, set to receive approximately $100 million in cash/annuity and multiple high-value international properties.
Trustees Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn are also major beneficiaries, set to receive $50 million and $25 million respectively, and have their outstanding debts to Epstein's entities forgiven.
Ghislaine Maxwell is listed as a beneficiary to receive $10 million.

The document includes a list of over 40 beneficiaries, many with redacted names, and establishes a $60 million litigation fund ($10M for trust validity claims, $50M for other claims against the estate).
